turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: The Court will hear argument first today in case 06-278, Morse vs. Frederick.
Mr. Starr.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Illegal drugs and the glorification of the drug culture are profoundly serious problems for our nation.
Congress has so recognized, as has this Court, time and again.

The magnitude of the problem is captured in the amicus brief, the Court has a number of amicus briefs before it, but the amicus brief of General McCaffrey, Secretary Bennett, and a number of organizations.
And particularly, pages 5 to 9 of that brief, the nature and the scope of the problem are well-captured.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, is this case limited to signs about drugs?
What is the rule that you want us to adopt for deciding this case?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: The rule the Court... that it articulated in Tinker.
The rule of the Court as articulated in Tinker is that there is, in fact, a right to political speech subject to disruption, requirements that the speech not be disruptive.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Disruptive of what?
Disruptive of the classroom order?
There was no classroom here.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Including but not limited to.
This was a school authorized event, this was education outside of the classroom.
It was essentially a school simply out of doors.
It was essentially--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, I can understand if they unfurled the banner in a classroom that it would be disruptive, but what did it disrupt on the sidewalk?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --The educational mission of the school.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but I mean, that's at a level of generality that doesn't get us very far.
I mean, what specifically did it disrupt?
Did it disrupt the parade, did it disrupt teaching, what was it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: 5520, a school policy of the board that says emphatically that political speech is protected, embracing Tinker.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then if that's the rule, the school can make any rule that it wants on any subject restrictive of speech, and if anyone violates it, the result is, on your reasoning, it's disruptive under Tinker.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Not at all.
I think that in form--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then I'm missing the argument.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --The argument is that this Court in Tinker articulated a rule that allows the school boards considerable discretion both in identifying the educational mission and to prevent disruption of that mission, and this is disruptive of the mission--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, suppose you have... suppose you have a mission to have a global school.
Can they ban American flags on lapel pins?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Absolutely not, because under Tinker that is political expression.
Let me be very specific.
This case is ultimately about drugs and other illegal substances.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So if the sign had been "Bong Stinks for Jesus", that would be, and Morse had the same reaction, that this was demeaning to the Olympics and it was unruly conduct, that there would be a protected right under Tinker because the message was not promoting drugs?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: She stated in her answers to interrogatories that she may very well not have interfered with the banner had it in fact said legalize marijuana.
Under our theory, we think she could have interfered with that because it was disruptive to the event, it was disorderly to the event itself, but the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What would be disorderly?
I don't understand this disorder.

If somebody holds up a sign and says change the marijuana laws, why is it disruptive of anything, simply because the school quite naturally has said we support the enforcement of the law, and the law right now does forbid the use of marijuana.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: It's political speech, it seems to me.
I don't see what it disrupts, unless disruption simply means any statement of disagreement with a position officially adopted by the school.
Is that what you mean by disruption?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --No.
Your Honor, first of all, this is, I think, an unusual characterization, namely for this to be called political speech.
We would--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If it's calling... I mean--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --We think it's a First... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --A call for a change in the law, I would have supposed, was political speech.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: That wasn't the interpretation.
Your Honor, let's back up, if I may.
Someone has to interpret the message and the front line message interpreter is the school official.
The school official--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that may be, but that's not the hypo.
The... the hypothetical is, what if there is a sign or a statement in the school calling for a change in, you know, the prohibition against marijuana use?
As a call for change in the law, I would suppose it was political speech.
But as I understood the argument you were making, it would still be regarded as an exception, as it were, to Tinker, because it was disruptive.
And it was disruptive in the sense that it disagreed with official school policy, which was to enforce the law or support the law as it was.
Is that your position on what disruption means under Tinker?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --But our... the answer is no.
Because what we are also urging the Court to consider is its gloss on Tinker and Frazier, and also what this Court said in Kuhlmeier.
And in Frazier, the Court was very clear, the first three paragraphs in part three of the opinion, in talking about the habits and manners of civility, and inculcating the values of citizenship.
That, in fact, is what is happening here.

There is an effort of the... to prevent a message that is inconsistent with a fundamental message of the schools, which is the use of illegal drugs is simply verboten, and we believe that is permitted under Tinker--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you want to get away from a hypothetical then.
I don't know why you try to defend a hypothetical that involves a banner that says amend the marijuana laws.
That's not this case as you see it, is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Well, it's certainly not this case, but--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This banner was interpreted as meaning smoke pot, no?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --It was interpreted... exactly, yes.
It was interpreted as an encouragement of the drug culture and--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Are you arguing that there should be a sui generis rule for speech that advocates illegal drug use, or this broader argument that the school can suppress any speech that is inconsistent with its educational mission as the school--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --I think that--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --defines it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --I apologize.

The Court can certainly decide this on very narrow grounds, that there are certain substances, illegal drugs, we would include alcohol and tobacco, that's part of the school's policy, because those are illegal substances which are very injurious to health.

And this Court has noted that in Bernonia and in Earls, time and again, it is that these are very dangerous substances and we have a clear policy sanctioned by Congress, and also noted by courts across the country, that illegal drugs are so dangerous that schools are entitled to have a message going--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But the problem... the problem, Mr. Starr, is that school boards these days take it upon themselves to broaden their mission well beyond education or protection from illegal substances, and several of the briefs have pointed out school boards have adopted policies taking on the whole range of political issues.
Now, do they get to dictate the content of speech on all of those issues simply because they have adopted that as the part of their educational mission?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --No, because that may very well be inconsistent with Tinker.
Tinker articulates a baseline of political speech is, in fact, protected, subject to--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that... I think you're right about that, and I guess my question goes to how broadly we should read Tinker.
I mean, why is it that the classroom ought to be a forum for political debate simply because the students want to put that on their agenda?

Presumably the teacher's agenda is a little bit different and includes things like teaching Shakespeare or the Pythagorean Theorem, and just because political speech is on the student's agenda, I'm not sure that it makes sense to read Tinker so broadly as to include protection of those, that speech.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --This Court has not read Tinker quite so broadly in both Frazier and in Kuhlmeier, and there are a couple of aspects of Tinker that I think are worthy of note.
One, that there was no written policy there, so there was an issue of standardless discretion being exercised.
And also--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it may have made a difference in Tinker.
If the school had a policy, defend our troops in Vietnam, would that have brought this into the category that you are now carving out?
You said that Tinker had no policy, but suppose the school did have a policy, patriotism, we support our troops, no bad speech about the war in Vietnam.
Should Tinker have come out the other way?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --No, it should not, because there... I think there are concerns with respect to what this Court has identified it is trying to, even in the public school setting, quite apart from the university setting, to cast a pall of orthodoxy to prevent the discussion of ideas.
What is happening here of course in this case, it can be decided very narrowly, that drugs, alcohol and tobacco just have no place in the schools.
And--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes, but the rule you proposed, I thought, in response to my question is that the school has wide discretion to define its educational mission and it can restrict speech that's inconsistent with that mission.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --And that's what this Court in--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And it seems to me that's much broader than Tinker.
Now you said, well, there is an exception for political speech.
Well, but then you're right with Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical, let's suppose that they have a particular view on a political issue, No Child Left Behind, or foreign intervention and so forth.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Justice Kennedy, the words that you articulated are essentially quotes of Frazier and Kuhlmeier, so there is a broadening of the lens and a restoration, frankly, of greater school discretion in those two cases than one might see in Tinker.

They of course drew, as you well know, from Justice Black's warning in dissent of Tinker that the Federal courts, Federal judiciary should not be extending itself unduly into the work of the school boards'--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why do we have to get into the question of what the school board's policy is and what things they can make its policy?
Surely it can be the... it must be the policy of any school to discourage breaking of the law.
I mean, suppose this banner had said kill somebody, and there was no explicit regulation of the school that said you should not, you should not foster murder.
Wouldn't that be suppressible?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Of course.
That is not--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course it would, so--

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --The answer is yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Why can't we decide this case on that narrow enough ground, that any school whether it has expressed the policy or not, can suppress speech that advocates violation of the law?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: I think it can, but it raises some interesting potential hypothetical questions, what about listening to the voice of Martin Luther King Junior, conscientious objection and so forth.
I don't think the Court needs to stray into those areas because here we have a written policy which does in fact respond to concerns about the exercise of standardless discretion.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Does it have--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me just clear up one thing to be 100 percent sure I understand your position.
It does... the message is the critical part of this case.
If it was a totally neutral message on a 15-foot sign, that would be okay.
You're not saying 15-foot signs are disruptive?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Not inherently disruptive, but in fact... the answer is yes.
We're not saying that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so we're focusing on the message and that's the whole crux of the case.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --That's why this case is here because of the message.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, why is that?
Why?
I mean suppose you go on a school trip, and the teacher says on the school trip, I don't want people unfurling 15 foot banners.
I don't care what they are about.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: It may very well be.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: We are going to visit the state capital and we are not marching down the street with 15 foot banners.
I mean, does the First Amendment say the teacher can't say that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: It does not.
But the Juneau school board and 5520, Justice Breyer, allows... in fact it has a Tinker statement in the first paragraph of 5520, which is also, you will not be advocating drugs.
And so there is essentially a culture of liberty in Juneau.
You don't have to--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You just said suppose... why should I not say that?
I mean I'm not going to do it, necessarily.
But why could I not say, would it be wrong in an opinion to say a school board can on a school trip tell the students they can't unfurl 15 foot banners?
Is that a correct statement of the law or not?
In your opinion.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --In my opinion it is a correct statement of the law.

But in response to Justice Stevens' question, the message here is in fact critical because what we know about this case is that, and you're here of course to respond to this case, which has to do with a message that the message interpreter, Deborah Morse, who by the way--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's also critical here to your case that it was a school event.
If it, if this had have been two blocks down the street there would have been no objection.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --If Mr. Frederick had seen fit to go down Glacier Avenue to J and J's, a popular hangout, there would have been no high school jurisdiction.
There may have been elementary school... but yes.
He could have gone, Justice Stevens, to the State capital or anywhere along the ten mile route.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Suppose it were Saturday instead of a weekday.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Suppose it were Saturday, not a school day.
And the school children were not required to show up at the Olympic event but were encouraged to and the same thing happened.
Would it make a difference that it wasn't in the course of a regular school day?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: No.
I think it still, under your hypothetical would be school sponsored.
But there might be a more difficult showing of disruption or inconsistency with the educational mission.

That is what this Court articulated in Frazier and again in Kuhlmeier that the school is able under our policies of federalism and value of federalism and democratic theory to fashion its educational mission subject to constitutional safeguards.

And that mission of preventing the schools from being infected with pro-drug messages continues wherever there is school jurisdiction, and that would include on a Saturday field trip or other kind of activity and I think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Mr. Starr, you... you responded to Justice Breyer that you think the school could just prohibit the unfurling of 15 foot banners on a trip.
Could it prohibit the wearing of black armbands on a trip?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --I don't believe so.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And if not... if not, what's the difference?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Because of the potential for disruption, disorderliness in the event and the judgment that is entrusted to--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But don't we have to be more specific about the context in determining whether there's disruption?
If it's a school trip to an art museum, unfurling a 15 foot banner in front of the pictures is clearly going to be disruptive of the object of the trip.
Unfurling a banner in a classroom is going to be disruptive to the teaching of Shakespeare or whatever is supposed to be going on in there.
What we have here is the unfurling of a banner on a sidewalk in a crowd with kids throwing snowballs waiting for some... somebody to run by with a TV camera nearby.
And there is a real question as to whether, it seems to me, as to whether it is in a kind of practical, real world sense, disruptive of anything.
And if there is such a question, shouldn't the answer favor the right to, to make the speech as opposed to favor the right to suppress it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Your Honor, the answer is no.

We do think that if the test that this Court has articulated which we embrace, looks not simply to "disruption" but inconsistency with what this Court has focused... this Court's language, the basic educational mission, then surely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.
Let me, let me follow, actually ask you the same question on... on that.
Because in response to Justice Scalia's question you said certainly that the school has got the right to have a policy that forbids violating the law and calling for violations of the law.
Accepting that as a premise, don't we need, before the school may suppress the speech, don't we need at least a statement which is clearly inconsistent with that policy?
And if that is so, is Bong Hits 4 Jesus inconsistent with it?
It sounds like just a kid's provocative statement to me.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Your Honor, with all due respect, the key is to allow the school official to interpret the message as long as that interpretation is reasonable.
You might disagree with that just as Justice Brennan disagreed with whether Matt Frazier's speech was all that terrible.
But he said even though it wasn't all that terrible I nonetheless defer to the interpretation of school officials.
That's what our educational system is about.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But those were the words and characterizing them as offensive/but here one could look at these words and say it's just nonsense.
Or one could say it's like mares-eat-oats.
It isn't clear that this is "smoke pot".

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Your Honor, again, Deborah Morse, a conscientious principal, interpreted the message in light of the subculture of the school where drug use is a serious problem.
And it was on the spot judgment.
We believe that judgment was reasonable as opposed to a judgment reached in judicial chambers, but we know that that was also the judgment of the superintendent and district judge--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that a judgment clear enough as a matter of law, or is there possible debate as to whether that's a reasonable interpretation of the message?
Let's assume it was an ambiguous message.
Would we have to accept her interpretation on summary judgment?

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: --Yes, I believe you do.
And... well, that's of course a question for the district judge.

And here the judge analyzed the facts in terms of what the individual was trying to say and determined that that is a reasonable interpretation and that is all that is required under this Court's law.
I'd like to reserve the remainder of my time.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Counsel.
Mr. Kneedler.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
The First Amendment does not require public school officials to stand aside and permit students who are entrusted to their supervision and care to promote or encourage the use of illegal drugs.
As this Court observed in Earls, the nationwide drug... drug epidemic makes the war against drugs a pressing concern in every school.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And is that the rationale on which you wish us to decide this case, nothing more broad?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: The Court need not decide anything more broadly than that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I'm asking what your recommendation is to what our rule should be this case.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, I think this is a manifestation of the principle articulated in Earls and repeated in Hazelwood that a, school does not have to tolerate a message that is inconsistent with its basic educational--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's a very... I find that a very, a very disturbing argument, because schools have and they can defined their educational mission so broadly that they can suppress all sorts of political speech and speech expressing fundamental values of the students, under the banner of, of... of getting rid of speech that's inconsistent with educational missions.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --That's why I think there would, there would be, it would make a lot of sense for the Court to articulate a rule that had to do with encouraging illegal conduct and particularly--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, why go into this?
I mean, that's what I actually, seriously don't understand.
Suppose the rule has the following rule: by the way, on our field trips you can carry around 15 foot banners.
They can say anything.
Except they can't talk about drugs and they can't talk about sex and they can't talk about... I don't know.
Or I'd say three things.
Would that be constitutional?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well... I think, I think a school could certainly prohibit the display of banners on a school trip or in a school assembly.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Suppose that this particular person had whispered to his next door neighbor,
"Bong Hits 4 Jesus, heh heh heh. "
you know.
Supposed that's what had happened?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: And that may well... that may well be different.
And that's why I--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No.
What would be different... that's what I... what a principal that has to act quickly sees across the street at a school meeting, a big banner go up making a joke out of drug use.
So the principal acts.
Now, are we supposed to divide that into little bitsy parts?
Because as soon as we do we are going to get a rather interesting, complicated and very difficult set of constitutional rules.
But you want us to do that.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --No.
I do not.

I think... I think the point that you make that a principal sees the banner across the street and sees the word bong hits, and... and at the very moment when the Olympic torch was about to arrive, I think it was.
She made a quick judgment and an entirely reasonable one that the display of the slang words bong hits--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, then you're not arguing for the broad educational mission, which is what you said at the first.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: Well, there are several gradations that the Court could take: Advocacy of illegal conduct generally; more specifically advocacy of illegal drugs.
But I believe... I think it's important to recognize that this Court's precedents recognize... recognize several different justifications for restricting student speech.

In Tinker itself which dealt with political speech, the Court was careful to point out that even then, if the speech could be shown to present a threat of a material disruption to the class work, and I think this would answer your question, Mr. Chief Justice, if the teacher wants to teach Shakespeare, the teacher doesn't have to turn over the class to political speech.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: But that's a viewpoint-neutral regulation.
This isn't, the principal didn't say this was a viewpoint-neutral regulation, did she?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --No.
No.

And... and, and just to finish, in Tinker even with a viewpoint concern, the Court said if you could show material disruption, and... and the Court made that clear in Tinker, by, by its comparison to several lower court decisions where wearing buttons had been prohibited because they had caused disruption.
And the third category in Tinker itself was where there would be an intrusion upon the rights of other students to be secure and be let alone.
That's Tinker dealing with political speech.
But in Frazier and Hazelwood the Court identified additional categories of speech that could be governed by the school, and this is in footnote 4 of Hazelwood.
The Court made clear that the ability to regulate those categories of speech goes beyond the question of whether there would be disruption or whether there would be--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So... so you think that the, not a 15 foot banner but a very discrete button that says "legalize marijuana", although it might be covered as not being disruptive under Tinker, it could be inconsistent with the school's mission and prohibited on that basis?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, I think... I think if, if the button is legalize marijuana during a referendum in the State, then that, that might be the category of political speech that could not be regulated.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And at... at this very rally, I mean I thought your brief said that it's okay to work for change in existing law which such a sign would be, but it is not okay to violate the law.
And no one was smoking pot in that crowd.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: But... but the, what was happening was a sign that was reasonably construed to encourage the use of illegal drugs.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.

Given the fact that this is a First Amendment case, isn't a court forced into the position if it's going to be consistent with what else we have said, even at the final appellate level, of giving pretty careful scrutiny to the statement itself in determining whether it may be suppressed or punished?
And if we do that, is it such a reasonable construction that this is an... an incitement to illegal drug use?
I mean it's a statement which makes, makes the drug law look a little ridiculous, I think, but I'm not sure that that is very distinguishable from a statement saying
"you ought to change the drug law. "

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, I... I... I think in, in this Court's decisions dealing with public schools, this Court has, has a consistent theme as to give deference to the judgments by the educators.
Public schools--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do we have to give... let me ask you this.
And maybe this is the, as far as we can go with it here.
Is that the answer to the question here about what the statement means?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In other words, if we give deference your argument wins.
But if we don't give deference, then does anybody really know what the statement means?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: I don't think the question is what Mr. Frederick intended.
The question is what a reasonable observer would think.
And the words "bong hits" are slang that would be particularly, have a particular characteristic of getting across to other student, and they suggest a casual tolerance and encouragement of--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What if the sign said "bong hits should be legal"?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --I, I think that would be a judgment call.
I think the, I think the casual use--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Under your view wouldn't the principal's judgment always prevail?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well it has to be a reasonable judgment and this is, this is reflected in Frazier.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that a question of fact or a question of law?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is whether it's a reasonable judgment--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: I think ultimately it's a question of law, whether it's a reasonable judgment.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: This, this... this parade had a theme to celebrate the Olympics, with... the high school kids are carrying the torch, the band is in it.
And suppose the banner said vote for, vote Republican, vote Democrat.
And he wants to be on the TV with that.
Could this, the principal make him take that sign out of the ground in that it's inconsistent with the whole theme of, of, of the parade?
Something like our Kurle case?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Yes.
I... I mean, I think for this reason.
This was essentially an outdoor assembly, where the... whether the students were assembled to watch a particular different, just as in an indoor assembly.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is that different from the rationale you've put.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Yes.
Again, that's why I don't think there's any one single rule that governs all cases.

This, this I think falls under the Frazier standard, where the Court said that, that schools have a duty to inculcate matters of civility and to prepare students for citizenship, and not violating the law is an important part of that and teachers' act in loco parentis.
They act as guardians and they should be able to do, as this Court says in Earls, what a reasonable guardian would do.
That would mean don't allow people to encourage lawbreaking.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it wasn't, it wasn't like an assembly, was it?
As I understand it, the children were released from school, but they were not required to attend this event and they were not required to stand in front of the school on the opposite side.
They weren't monitored by their teachers, so they... and there were nonstudents in the crowd.
So it's not like a school assembly.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: The students' present at the event, presence as the event, was like an assembly.
Students may go into an assembly hall and not have to sit with their class.
They were released from class, but they were not released from school or school supervision.

There were teachers around there and the school could define what is the nature of our assembly at this public event and, just as in, in the auditorium a school could say there will be no political banners or, frankly, no banners about anything other than what the event is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Were they required to go to this event and could they have skipped off and gone home without violating--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --They were not allowed to go home.
They were required, they were required--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --They were required to attend.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --They were required to be there if the classroom teacher decided to let them go out there, but they were under school supervision at that time.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Were they ever told what they were supposed to do in the sense did the school ever say, we are letting you out on the street to celebrate the Olympics and to do only that?
Was, was there an object to this release from the school building that was ever conveyed?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: If I may, I don't think there's any question that he knew in advance that this was about the Olympics.
That's why he made the sign.
And they were released to go out and watch the torch go by.
He hasn't raised any question of notice or due process concerns.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Kneedler.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Mertz.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court: This is a case about free speech.
It is not a case about drugs.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: It's a case about money.
Your client wants money from the principal personally for her actions in this case.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: He does have a damages claim against the school district and the principal, but that's by no means his chief object here.
The overwhelming object is to assert his free speech--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, would you waive damages against this principal who has devoted her life to the school, and you're seeking damages for her for this sophomoric sign that was held up?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --We are certainly willing to negotiate a minimum settlement of damages.
That is not the object here.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But there's a broader issue of whether principals and teachers around the country have to fear that they're going to have to pay out of their personal pocket whenever they take actions pursuant to established board policies that they think are necessary to promote the school's educational mission.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: That is indeed a legitimate fear, Your Honor, and we believe the existing law takes care of it by requiring before qualified immunity can be breached that there be a demonstration that under the existing law at the time available to her--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And you think it was clearly established that she had to allow a student at a school-supervised function to hold a 15-foot banner saying 4 Jesus> ["]?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I think it was clearly established at the time, Your Honor, that a principal could not engage in viewpoint censorship of a nondisruptive expression, under both Ninth Circuit law and this Court's law.
The case had--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Does that, does that general statement that you just made apply to all circumstances in which a student-teacher relationship might be involved?
For example, in the course of teaching a class in Shakespeare would your rule prevail?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --The rule on qualified immunity?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, the general rule which the teacher is supposed clearly to have known here.
For example, in the Shakespeare class, kid doesn't, doesn't say anything.
He doesn't yell or scream or even raise his hand.
He just holds a little sign in the Shakespeare class that says 4 Jesus> ["].

As I understood the general rule that you said the teacher was bound to know here, the teacher I suppose would be required or the school would be required to tolerate that sign in the Shakespeare class; is that correct?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I believe the analysis would be the Tinker analysis in terms of substantial disruption of the lesson.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, would there be a substantial disruption?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: It would all depend on the circumstances.
My guess is that if it were simply passively--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If the kids look around and they say, well, so and so has got his bong sign again--
[Laughter]
--they then return, they then return to MacBeth.
Does the... does the, does the teacher have to, does the school have to tolerate that sign in the Shakespeare class?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I believe that in circumstances where it is a substantial distraction--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Can't it just say no signs when you're supposed to be learning?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Your Honor, I think the answer is yes if they had a content-neutral rule prohibiting signs in school.
I believe that would be--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But can't the school decide that it's part of its mission to try to prevent its student from engaging in drug use and so that it's going to have a viewpoint on drug use and that viewpoint is going to be that it's opposed to it and so that it takes a particular view with respect to signs that in their view seem to encourage drug use?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Certainly it is within the school's mission to discourage drug use.
Certainly it has many tools to allow it to get its own viewpoint... certainly it can... it does not need to provide a forum in the school itself for students with a contrary viewpoint.
But when a student is basically on his own time, whether it's outside of school--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So your position would be different if this were in the student gym and they were having a discussion.
There was a program to discourage drug use and he held up his sign; you would say it would be all right to take down the sign inside the school gym?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --No, I'm not so sure.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So it doesn't matter that this is outside.
It matters on the content of the sign, not the location?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Well, what matters is whether there is a substantial disruption of what the school is trying to achieve legitimately, whether it's a classroom lesson or a lesson on drug use.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, but the school has... the school has a program, an anti-drug program that shows movies, it brings in policemen and social workers to preach against drug use and you're saying that... never mind unfurling a banner.
You're saying that it has to let students contradict this message it's trying to teach, to walk around, you know, with a button that says "Smoke Pot, It's Fun".

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Does the school have to do that?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I believe, Your Honor, that a nondisruptive pin, badge, whatever you want to call it, would have to be tolerated.
However, they would not have to tolerate a student who interrupts a anti-drug presentation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But the school, even though it is trying to teach one point of view, can allow students to come in and undermine that point of view, assuming that it's legitimate to teach that point of view?
It can allow students to come in and undermine what it's trying to teach?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that is not disruption in your view?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I think they cannot prevent presentation of a contrary viewpoint as long as it is done in such a way that it doesn't interfere with the school's own presentation of its viewpoint.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Can the student be allowed to wear a button that says "Rape Is Fun"?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: No, I don't think so--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --There is a distinction there.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Because when you're talking about hate speech, speech that advocates violence, then you're in another category of speech.
There has been general recognition--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Nonviolent crimes are okay, it's only violent crimes that you can't, you can not promote, right?
Right?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I think there is a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: "Extortion Is Profitable", that's okay?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This is a very, very, with all respect, ridiculous line.
I mean, I can understand you're saying you cannot promote things that are unlawful, but to say, oh, it's only violent, where do you get that line from, only violent unlawful acts?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --No, I'm not saying only violent unlawful acts.

But this is a case where if you look at it in the context of what was going on in the State at the time, where there was an active public debate on marijuana policy, on marijuana for medical use, marijuana for personal use, so it's--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So it's a political... even assuming it's a political issue, the question is whether the school has to say our classrooms, our field trips, our sponsored and supervised activities are a forum for that debate?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I believe it does not have to if being a forum would disrupt the school's own educational program and--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And disruption does not include undermining the message they want to send?
It has to be some type of physical disruption.
But undermining the message they want to send, they can't make the judgment that that's not allowed?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Preventing a contrary viewpoint from being expressed, that we--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but you rephrased it that way, but what actually happened is the principal looks across the street, a 15-foot banner goes up at what's supposed to be a school event with everybody together in a single place, and it says a joke, it makes a joke out of drug use.

The principal thinks of course adolescents and post-adolescents sometimes like to test limits, and if the kids go around having 15-foot banners making a joke out of drug use that really does make it a little tougher for me to convince the students at this school not to use drugs, and particularly putting up 15-foot banners.

I don't know why everybody wants to get away from that because I think you would have had a very different case if in fact it had been a whisper or if it had been a serious effort to contest the drug laws.
It wasn't either.
It was a joke.
It was a 15-foot banner.
We have the message plus the means plus the school event.
Now, what's your response?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --My response, Your Honor, is that, first of all, a 14-foot banner.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That's an excellent response, I think.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: That was just a preliminary.
In fact, what it was was a person displaying this banner in a quiet, passive manner that didn't interfere with anybody's observation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I conceive that interference consists of it's pretty hard to run a school where kids go around at public events publicly making a joke out of drugs.
That's what his thought is.
Now, I don't think he has to be able to read content discrimination, viewpoint discrimination, time-place.
He doesn't know the law, the principal.
His job is to run the school.
And so I guess what I'm worried about is a rule that would... is on your side, a rule that takes your side; we'll suddenly see people testing limits all over the place in the high schools.
But a rule that against your side may really limit people's rights on free speech.
That's what I'm struggling with.
Now, I want some help there and I'm worried about the principal.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I believe the answer is that the Tinker case as we understand it struck a very wise compromise between allowing school officials to have complete discretion to suppress student speech in order to maintain what they conceive of as their individual mission and the student's right to speak in a nondisruptive manner.
The speaker... the Tinker case has stood the test of time for 40, almost 30 years and, although--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you can say that, but the subsequent cases seem to me to try to cut back on it.
I mean, it stood the test of time in the sense that it hasn't been overruled, but--

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --There have been some narrow exceptions to it in subsequent cases, of course, the Frazier and the Kuhlmeier cases.
But the basic, the heart of it, the requirement that the school demonstrate that substantial disruption before it can engage in suppression of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I think we're using disruption in two different senses here and we should probably separate the two.
One sense is disrupting the class so that whatever is being taught can't be taught.
But you're also using it in the sense of undermining a general message that the school is trying to get across: Obey the law, don't use drugs, whatever.
Maybe we should have a different word for... the first is disruption.
Disruption is a, is a funny word for the second.
Let's called it undermining instead.
Now, you think both of them, however, are bad and both of them can be a basis for suppressing the speech?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --If I understand your question correctly, the second of them might better be called allowing competing viewpoints.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you think undermining is perfectly okay?
You would never consider undermining to be disruption and therefore bad?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I think undermining in the sense of preventing impeding the school from delivering its--
own message--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, but only that.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --would be substantial disruption.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right after a class on drugs, he can be standing there in the hall and say: This class was ridiculous, drugs are good for you, I use them all the time, I urge all of you.
That's perfectly okay?
That's not undermining?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I believe that is the kind of speech--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's not disruption?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --that we must tolerate no matter how unwise it is.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But couldn't the school, couldn't the school board have a time, place, or manner regulation that says you're not going to use the halls to proselytizer for your cause, whatever it may be?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I believe that's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You could have reasonable rules of decorum for what goes on inside the school building.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Does the school have to be completely neutral in that respect?
Does it have to punish who says that was a good program, I'm not going to use drugs, and you shouldn't either, because he's taking position on a public issue?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I think a content neutral, content neutrality is critical here, and if the school wants to allow anti-drug comments, messages, then it has an outside of the official forum--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Where does that notion that our schools have to be content neutral... I thought we wanted our schools to teach something, including something besides just basic elements, including the character formation and not to use drugs.
They have to be neutral on whether you should use drugs or not?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Content neutrality goes to what speech is suppressed or punished.
As far as the school delivering its own message, there is no requirement of equal time or that it be neutral.
It's got its own viewpoint in the case of drugs, a viewpoint that almost all of us agree with, and it should be able to espouse--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A school isn't an open forum.
A school isn't there for everybody to teach the students whatever he wants.
It's there for the teachers to instruct.
And you're turning it into an open forum.
If the school says, addresses one issue, everybody else has to be able to address that issue.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I don't believe that's the case at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's not my vision of what a school is.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: In the classroom delivering the prescribed messages, in the school assemblies, when the school wishes to present a particular message, that's one case.

However, in the lunchroom, outside in recess, across the street, that is a quintessentially open forum where it would not be proper, I think, to tell students you may not mention this subject, you may not take this position.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But do you concede that there was some right of school control for what was going on across the street?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: No.
Actually our primary position on that is that he was in a public place at a public event among public people--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: If kids were throwing bottles and injuring passers by, the principal had no right or duty to go over there and stop it?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Oh, I think if they were engaging in an act of hooliganism--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, that's because the school has a right of control.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --There is a distinction here.
This young man had not been in school today, had not been an campus, was not in any class that was released to--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why did he go where he went?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why did he choose that location to unfurl his banner?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: He explained because it was the only place where he actually knew the route of the relay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I mean, that's... I have, I guess his note, you accept this with what the teacher said.
The entire class went to view the relay.
Individual students... this is at 9:30 in the morning.
They were not given the option of remaining in class, nor were they released to do as they pleased.

They were to watch the relay with the rest of the student body, either just in front of the school or just across the street... that's me, not them... and then return directly to their classrooms, which I guess the school did.
So it sounds like you're going to one place, stand together, behave yourselves, watch the relay, and the teachers will be there and take you back to class.
Now is there something else in the record that suggests something different?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: There is a major dispute on that point, Your Honor.
We presented several affidavits that showed individual teachers--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Just tell me where to look.
Where are the conflicting affidavits?
I'm just reading from page 51 of the joint appendix.
I didn't know there was a dispute.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --It would be on pages 32, 34, 36.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay, I'll look at those.
Another somewhat minor point.
Can I ask you another point about the record?
I'll read those.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Okay.
Can I finish the description of what actually happened?
According to the students, for those who were released from class, there was no requirement for staying on campus, and many of them did not stay on campus.
No requirement for--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, they went across the street.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Some of them did.
Some went down--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Was there any... there was no requirement, they didn't have to go across the street or stay on campus, they could wander off distantly.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --They could, and many of them did.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: And there was no requirement that they stay together, no requirement that they do anything in particular.
They--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I had to watch... not even watch the parade, no requirement they watch the parade?
They were released in order to watch the parade.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --That was the intent, obviously, for those released.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The intent, it was the direction.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It was not only the intent, it was the direction.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Actually it was not.
According to these student affidavits, they were simply released and said, you can go watch--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Was there any fact finding on that?
You referred to affidavits.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --No.
It was decided on cross motions for summary judgment in the district court, and there were no findings, actually no factual findings at all, and certainly nothing on that particular point.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can I ask you another record point, just so I know where to look?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You've also asked for an injunction that would require expunging his 5-day suspension from his record.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: 10 days.
Well, 10 or 5, unclear.
I noticed the superintendent of schools on page 66A when he's reviewing this, what he says is,
"Joseph contends that all his behavior is excusable because he was exercising his free of speech right. "
"Even if I were to concede his speech across from the high school is protected, which I do not, the rest of his behavior warranted the suspension. "
And then he says,
"And I'm cutting it from 10 days to 5. "

"So given that, if you win, suppose you were to win, and you... that it is protected and so forth... then would you concede or not concede the suspension, the 5 days, it's over, it still stands, I don't care about the expungement or not? "

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: The... whether it remains on the record, anything that remains on his record is obviously much more--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, but I'm asking that you think about it.
I'm putting you on the spot.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --In that case, I missed the point of your--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I want to know what the superintendent said.
As I read it is, he says, look, I don't care if this was protected or not.
I'll give you that.
It's protected.
But the rest of his behavior, the way he treated the principal, what he did, the reluctance, et cetera, et cetera, that warrants a suspension too, and I'm cutting it from 10 days to 5.
So it sounds to me as I read it that the teacher is saying even if you're right, he's still suspended for 5 days.
That's what the superintendent says.
Now suppose you win your point that you're interested in winning, which you may not or you may.
Are you still then going to pursue this case on the 5 days, that that should be erased?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --If the only thing left were discipline because he was tardy that day, was... didn't divulge the names of the other people holding the banner, that sort of thing, we couldn't--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I think it's--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You couldn't what?
I didn't hear the last part of what you said.
You just got to the point of--

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Of answering the question.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Yes.
What's the answer?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Those things wouldn't manner anymore.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So you would not pursue it?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Can we get back... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Can we get back to what the case is about.

You think the law was so clearly established when this happened that the principal, that the instant that the banner was unfurled, snowballs are flying around, the torch is coming, should have said oh, I remember under Tinker I can only take the sign down if it's disruptive.
But then under Frazier I can do something if it interferes with the basic mission, and under Kuhlmeier I've got this other thing.
So she should have known at that point that she could not take the banner down, and it was so clear that she should have to pay out of her own pocket because of it.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, there are two different time points we have to talk about.

There's the heat of the moment out there on the street, but then later back in the office when she actually decided to levy the punishment after she had talked to him, after she heard why he did it and why he didn't do it, after she had had a chance to consult with the school district's counsel.
At that point in the calmness of her office, then she should indeed have known it.
And she did testify that she had taken a master's degree course in school law in which she studied Kuhlmeier and Frazier and Tinker.
So--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And so it should be perfectly clear to her exactly what she could and couldn't do.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: As it is to us, right?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I mean, we have had a debate here for going on 50 minutes about what Tinker means, about the proper characterization of the behavior, the nonspeech behavior.
The school's terms in dealing with the kids that morning.
The meaning of the, of the statement.
We've been debating this in this courtroom for going on an hour, and it seems to me however you come out, there is reasonable debate.
Should the teacher have known, even in the, in the calm deliberative atmosphere of the school later, what the correct answer is?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: We believe at the very least she should have known that one cannot punish a nondisruptive holding of a sign because it said something you disagreed with.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Of course I disagree with the characterization on disruptive.
It was completely disruptive of the message, of the theme that the school wanted to promote.
Completely disruptive of the reason for letting the students out to begin with.
Completely disruptive of the school's image that they wanted to portray in sponsoring the Olympics.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Well, they weren't sponsoring the Olympics, they weren't even sponsoring this event actually.
They simply let the students out to watch it.
That was--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Some of the students were carrying the torch and the band was playing in the parade.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --A few of the student... a few of the relay runners were from the school and had been allowed to skip school because of that, and the pep band played as it went by.
I do not believe that made the torch relay a school event.
The best that can be said for them is that they let the students watch it with the concurrence of individual teachers, and that that attendance was a school sanctioned attendance.
Now whether that allows them to then engage in this kind of punishment for speech by a student who was not even among those released, who is standing--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Now you said that in your brief, and I couldn't understand that somehow you got mileage out of his being truant that morning.
Would the case have come out differently, would you be making any different argument if he got to school on time and was released with the rest of them?
Does the case turn on the fact that he was late to school that day?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --We believe it would be a closer question, but the fact that he was not there in school today, and intentionally was not there today, turns this into a pure free speech case where you have a citizen in a public place in a public event who was not acting as a student.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So he's not a school child, he would be playing hooky?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Because he was playing hooky because he chose not to be there, because he was not part of the class.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Even though the law required him to be there?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He wasn't playing hooky.
He showed up late, that's all, right?
I mean, he actually came and joined his classmates at an event that he knew was an event that the school told the classes to go to.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: He joined--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: As far as I'm concerned, he just showed up late.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --He joined a public crowd on a private side... public sidewalk in front of private homes.
The crowd happened to have some other students in that school there.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Where did he go immediately after?
He went to the school building for whatever it was, the third period of the day.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Yes.
The principal instructed him to do so and he did.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So under your view, if the principal sees something wrong in the crowd across the street, had to come up and say now, how many here are truants and how many here are... I can't discipline you because you're a truant, you can go ahead and throw the--
bottle.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: No, I don't think she needs to do that in the heat of the moment.
But later on once she's discovered the true facts, then at that point I think she loses a basis for punishing him as a student if he was not there as a student.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Because you're both a truant and disrupter, you get off.
[Laughter]
Had you been just a disrupter, tough luck.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Well, it may well be that he could have been punished for being truant, but of course that's not why we're here.
He was punished for displaying, for the content of the sign he was displaying in a public place as a private citizen.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Who were the people that helped him hold up his flag?
Were they not classmates of his?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: Most of them were classmates; at least one was not a student.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Did he not know that these classmates were there at a public event that was sponsored, not sponsored, but to which the school had--
directed the students to go?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: I'm sure he did know.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So it seems to me it's like joining a school trip at the zoo, you know.
You... you don't make it to the... to the school, but you drive there yourself and then join the class as it's going through the zoo.
It seems to me he's in school.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: A better analogy might be if he had gone on his own time to the zoo and was engaging in some expressive act, and there happened to be a school group there at the same time, could the teacher with that group then have disciplined him for what he was doing?

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: That gets back to the point I was trying to make earlier.
He came here because it was the school event, the school sponsored activity.
He could have gone anywhere along the route.
He knew that it was coming by the school, he knew that they were going to be, the students were going to be released to see it.
He went to join up with the school even if he were truant that day.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I believe that's incorrect.
There is nothing in the record that even suggests that he went there in order to join up with schoolmates or in order to be near the school.
He says, in fact, he intentionally tried to avoid the school because he thought that that way he could avoid the school jurisdiction for his--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You think he could have been marked absent for the whole day because he didn't intend to be part of the school group afterwards?
I mean, suppose there's a suspension of so much for half a day truancy, and so much more for a whole day's truancy.
And he shows up and he says, oh, you can't... you have to hold me for a whole day's truancy because I didn't intend to be in school.
I was in school but I didn't intend to be there.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I think it would all depend on whether he--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That doesn't make any sense to me.
Does it depend on his intent, whether or not he intended to be a truant that afternoon?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I think that would depend on the fact of whether he was a truant that afternoon.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He was either in school or he wasn't in school.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: In the morning he wasn't in school.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: In the afternoon he either was or he wasn't.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: In the afternoon he was.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the question is whether joining the school group, intentionally joining the school group, going there because the school group was there, whether that places him in school.

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: As a hypothetical, if he were intentionally joining a school group, I would have to say that puts him within whatever jurisdiction the school has.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why does it matter?
That is, why doesn't the... you're suing the teacher or the principal and why wouldn't the issue be what that principal really reasonably thought the situation was?

I mean, if a principal reasonably thought he was part of the school group, if the principal reasonably thought that this was a school outing, if the principal reasonably thought that students are staying together, why wouldn't that just be the ground on which you'd take the case, we should take it that way, because the principal reasonably thinks?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: As far as qualified immunity, I think that's correct, if she had a reasonable belief.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But even on the merits?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: On the merits I don't think so, because if he was not in fact there as part of a school group--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Even if the principal couldn't tell him to take down the manner even if she thought he was part of the school group reasonably, if he really wasn't?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --I do not believe there's anything in the law that allows a principal to convert a pure free speech exercise into a school exercise because it's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought you were going to appeal to the calm of her office the next day.
I thought that was going to be your answer to my question.
Whatever she thought at the time, she didn't think it later.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: May I ask to you clarify one thing.
I initiated this line of questioning when I said I was surprised that your brief made such a big deal that he was late to school.

You would still be making the argument about the free speech right if he had diligently showed up for his math class first period in the morning, gone out with the others, and had his banner to unfurl when the torch came by?

turn.speaker: douglas_k_mertz
turn.label: Mr. Douglas K. Mertz
turn.text: --That is correct.
We have two independent bases for defending him here.
One is the pure free speech in a public place argument.
That's the one that hinges on the fact that he was not among the released students.

The other argument, which we believe in equally, is that even if it were a on-campus or on an extension of campus like a field trip, then under Tinker because it was not disruptive they cannot punish it.
My time is up.
I thank the Court.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Mertz.
Mr. Starr, you have a minute remaining.

turn.speaker: kenneth_w_starr
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth W. Starr
turn.text: For the reasons that have been discussed, under no circumstances should Deborah Morse, a conscientious principal, be subjected to the possibility of punitive damages or compensatory damages.
A very brief factual point.
In light of the richness of the discussion with respect to the facts, I would guide the Court to page 109 of the joint appendix.
This is Deborah Morse's interrogatory answer and there she sets forth the facts, and that bleeds into the law.
To promote drugs... and this is our fundamental suggestion and submission.

To promote drugs is utterly inconsistent with the basic educational mission of the school, and for this Court to suggest to the contrary would really be quite inconsistent with much of its drug jurisprudence, Bernonia and Earls.
The opinion of the Court in Earls 2002 is especially powerful with respect to the scourge of drugs and their dangers.
More broadly, the Court does not need to go more broadly, but the Court has spoken more broadly with respect to the need to defer to school officials in identifying the educational mission.
But we know that there are in fact constitutional limits.
Those limits are captured in Tinker.

A passive pure political speech that reflects on the part of the school board a standardless discretionary effort to squelch any kind of controversial discussion, that casts a pall of orthodoxy over the classroom.
We are light years away from that.
I thank the Court.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you counsel, the case is submitted.
